citation.article-title: Pseudoalteromonas peptidolytica sp. nov., a novel marine mussel-thread-degrading bacterium isolated from the Sea of Japan.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudoalteromonas peptidolytica sp. nov.
Pseudoalteromonas peptidolytica (pep.ti.do.ly'ti.ca. Gr. n. peptos a class of organic compounds; Gr. adj. lytica dissolving; M.L. fem. adj. peptidolytica peptide repeats dissolving)
Cells of the type strain are rod-shaped.
They are 2-3 μm in length and 0.7-0.8 μm in diameter.
Colonies on marine agar medium are circular, smooth, convex with regular edges and yellow-pigmented.
Sodium ions are essential for growth.
Able to grow at 15-40 °C with optimum growth at 30 °C.
Produces cytochrome oxidase, catalase, gelatinase, lipase, amylase and alginase.
Aerobically utilizes maltose, succinate, fumarate, glucose and N-acetylglucosamine.
Does not produce H2S from thiosulfate or denitrify.
Does not produce β-galactosidase, arginine dihydrolase or lysine and ornithine decarboxylases.
Based on both 16S rDNA and gyrB nucleotide sequences, this bacterium belongs to the γ-Proteobacteria and is a member of the genus Pseudoalteromonas.
The type strain F12-50-A1T (=MBICC F1250A1T) was isolated from the surface waters of the Yamato Islands, in the Sea of Japan.
